Harrison Liao

Featured

Looking Back on the Bizarre Joakim Noah Signing

What were the Knicks doing? We asked that in July and we’re still asking it

Flash back to summer 2016 . The New York Knicks need a center after trading Robin Lopez to the Chicago Bulls in order to acquire Derrick Rose, who the Knicks signed to a $21 million one-year deal. Who better to fill the void than former Defensive Player of the Year, 2014 All-NBA first-team center, and Rose’s running mate from the Chicago Bulls, Joakim Noah?

By most accounts, catering to Rose was the main reason for signing Noah. Rose and Noah got along well in Chicago, where they also shared the best seasons of their respective careers. Rose became the youngest player ever, at age 22, to win league MVP. Noah earned a reputation as one of the fiercest competitors on the court, as well as a skilled big. He was quick, could get to the free-throw line, and was one of the best low-post passers in the world. If you put yourself in the Knicks’ shoes, you can (kind of) see the logic behind reuniting the two. In a vacuum, the move works.

But the Knicks are not a vacuum. They’re run by James Dolan, Phil Jackson, and Steve Mills, and they ended up inking Noah to a four year, $72.6 million contract. I understand signing Noah to a one-year expiring like Rose, and even overpaying him a little. That’s a decent gamble for one of the best centers in the league when healthy (a massive “if”). He’s worth a shot if you think there’s a chance he regains 75 percent of what he was at his obnoxious, franchise-changing peak, and if you think he can help Rose get back to 75 percent of his MVP level, that’s a deal you have to make. But $18 million a year is not a slight overpay, it’s salary-cap suicide. It gets worse when you look at the contract details; Noah is on a “poison-pill” contract, meaning his salary starts low and increases each season, making him virtually untradeable if his stock tanks.

Which it has, to put it nicely. Even in his prime, Noah was a safe bet to miss about 15 games per season, so on Monday morning when Adrian Wojnarowski of Yahoo! announced that Noah would miss the rest of the season, Knicks fans were hardly surprised.

Just In: Joakim Noah Will Miss the Rest of 2016–17 Season
Four years, $72 milliontheknickswall.com

His injury put the nail in the coffin, but New York fans all kind of knew: the Noah deal is yet another major blunder by one of the most incompetent front offices in the league. With a truckload of cap space in the Summer of 2016 for a loaded free agency — and with Carmelo Anthony on the back-nine of his prime — the Knicks had a short window to either retool their roster for the future or write a big check for a win-now monster. And they had plenty of options to dive down either path.

Sure, they weren’t getting Kevin Durant or LeBron James. In all fairness, they weren’t getting Andre Drummond (restricted, and the Pistons were ready to match any offer), Mike Conley (only the Grizzlies can offer him the super-max), DeMar DeRozan (same as Conley, but with the Raptors), or Bradley Beal (again, super-max). But there were a lot of attainable guys for New York, especially when you take into account their cap space, the allure of playing for the Knicks, and a ‘Melo/Kristaps Porzingis core.

The “Let’s Get Younger” Route

  • Tyler Johnson, 24, explosive combo guard (signed for four years, $50 million)
  • Terrence Jones, 25, small-ball big that can face up and run the floor (signed for one year, $1 million)
  • Meyers Leonard, 25, more athletic but worse shooting Channing Frye (signed for four years, $41 million)
  • Maurice Harkless, 23, small-ball big that can guard several positions (signed for four years, $40 million)
  • Harrison Barnes, 24, young star that’s an ideal secondary option on a good team (signed for a four year max worth $94 million)
  • Jordan Clarkson, 24, fiery defender with legit size for a point guard and decent offensive skills (signed for four years, $50 million)

The “Win Now” Route

  • Al Horford, 30, uber-versatile big that can guard multiple positions and shoot from the outside (signed for four years, $113 million)
  • Pau Gasol, 36, not a star anymore but still a valuable stretch-center (signed for two years, $31.6 million)
  • Arron Afflalo, 31, big guard that can guard multiple positions and score off the bench (signed for two years, $25 million)
  • Ian Mahinmi, 30, fluid center that can anchor an interior defense with Porzingis (signed for four years, $65 million)
  • Jared Dudley, 31, 3-and-D forward that can take the pressure off ‘Melo to guard power forwards, also a stabilizing locker-room presence (signed for three years, $30 million)
  • Dwight Howard, 31, still a double-double threat every night and an above-average rim protector (signed for three years, $70 million)
Oh No, This Could Be Bad
The tanking Knicks are re-evaluating their roster in the eyes of their backwards presidenttheknickswall.com

The notion, at the time of the Rose/Noah signings, was that the Knicks had gambled on a win-now “superteam.” In fact, what they had done was pay win-now money to guys that don’t make their team better. Sure, they appeared to commit to the the win-now route (which, with Porzingis on the roster, is almost certainly a mistake, but that’s a topic for another day), but they didn’t even chase the right win-now players. The only productive signings that summer were Courtney Lee and Brandon Jennings, but they both need a solid foundation around them to be difference-makers, which the Knicks don’t have. And if you want to nitpick, the Lee deal was sloppy too. Even though Jared Dudley offers a lot of the same stuff as Lee and was available for three years, $30 million, the Knicks ended up paying Lee $50 million over four years.

I should point out that most free agents don’t just blindly sign with a team because they offer them the most money. Money is a major factor in making a decision in the summer, but there are other valuations, and each guy has different priorities. Pau Gasol is not coming to an organization like the Knicks for the same deal he got from the Spurs. He wants to compete for a title. He wants to play for a stable franchise run by the likes of Gregg Popovich and R.C. Buford. He wants to play with Kawhi Leonard and LaMarcus Aldridge. The Knicks don’t have any of those things. It’s going to take a lot more than what Gasol got from the Spurs (two years, $31.6 million) to accept playing for the Knicks, and a price tag that high means Gasol probably isn’t a great fit for the Knicks either. There’s mutual disinterest there. Gasol doesn’t want to play for an awful organization, and the awful organization on the other end doesn’t want to max out an aging star that is now a role player.

But guess what? That’s exactly what the Knicks did! They locked down Joakim Noah, a legitimate needle-mover four years ago, for a deal he deserved four years ago! It’s moves like these that make the Knicks an awful organization that repels free agents. That kind of stench doesn’t just magically appear, especially with the attractions New York has to offer. In fact, there’s a ton of reasons to consider the Knicks if you’re a free agent. Kristaps Porzingis might be a top-10 player in a few years. Carmelo Anthony already shoulders all the media and other external pressure, so you don’t have to worry about that. And playing in Madison Square Garden still matters to NBA guys. It’ll always be sacred ground for them. DeMar DeRozan just told Zach Lowe as much on his “Lowe Post” podcast Monday. It’s not the dim lights, it’s not the celebrities. There’s just something special about the Mecca of basketball.

Which makes it even sadder that the Knicks can’t leverage any of their strengths. The weakness of their front office overshadows everything, from attracting free agents to making roster changes to hiring the right coaching staff. Signing Derrick Rose might not have been the best use of a $21 million cap hold, but it was at least defensible. There was a tiny chance that he might still be great (which he’s not, although he’d still be devastating as an off-the-bench scorer for a championship team), and an expiring deal is a tradeable asset no matter what. In the right context, signing Joakim Noah makes sense too. Put him on a one-year track as well, so if the Rose gamble goes south then Noah and the Knicks aren’t left in a lose-lose situation. And don’t overpay him to the point where it cripples your cap space. Don’t give a 32-year-old center with a history of knee issues a poison-pill contract worth $72 million.

Look, I get it. When they signed him, Noah was one of the last serviceable bigs left in free agency and the Knicks had to meet the salary floor. But if that was the case, it was their responsibility to act faster. Start calling free-agent targets earlier, and if those guys were never going to come then it’s time to take a hard look at whether ownership has damaged the Knicks’ reputation beyond repair.

There’s still a chance this deal works out. Not great odds, but the medical process behind treating knee issues is way ahead of what it was fifteen years ago. Noah could potentially come back and continue to rebound at an elite rate — he was close to the tops of the charts for rebounds per 100 possessions when he played this season — and up his stock just enough so that the Knicks can trade him. But with his recent knee surgery (which is on the same knee he required surgery for with the Bulls, by the way), year one of the Noah Experiment is officially in the books. And it’s been a complete catastrophe.

— Harrison Liao, site writer
